Generation I.Red: Capable of swimming backwards by rapidly flapping its wing-like pectoral fins and stout tail.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Capable of swimming backwards by rapidly flapping its wing-like pectoral fins and stout tail.
Generation I.Yellow: Touching the back fin causes numbness. It hooks its tail to coral to stay in place while sleeping.
Generation I.Stadium: A clever Pokémon that can swim backwards while facing forward. Fainting may result from a jab of its sharp spikes.

Generation II.Gold: An examination of its cells revealed the presence of a gene not found in Horsea . It became a hot topic.
Generation II.Silver: Its fin-tips leak poison. Its fins and bones are highly valued as ingredients in herbal medicine.
Generation II.Crystal: The male raises the young. If it is approached, it uses its toxic spikes to fend off the intruder.
Generation II.Stadium 2: An examination of its cells revealed the presence of a gene not found in Horsea . It became a hot topic. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) Its fin-tips leak poison. Its fins and bones are highly valued as ingredients in herbal medicine. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Seadra sleeps after wriggling itself between the branches of coral. Those trying to harvest coral are occasionally stung by this Pok é mon 's poison barbs if they fail to notice it.
Generation III.Sapphire: Seadra generates whirlpools by spinning its body. The whirlpools are strong enough to swallow even fishing boats. This Pok é mon weakens prey with these currents, then swallows it whole.
Generation III.Emerald: The poisonous barbs all over its body are highly valued as ingredients for making traditional herbal medicine. It shows no mercy to anything approaching its nest.
Generation III.FireRed: Its body bristles with sharp spikes. Carelessly trying to touch it could cause fainting from the spikes.
Generation III.LeafGreen: It is capable of swimming backwards by rapidly flapping its winglike pectoral fins and stout tail.

Generation IV.Diamond: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation IV.Pearl: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation IV.Platinum: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation IV.HeartGold: An examination of its cells revealed the presence of a gene not found in Horsea . It became a hot topic.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Its fin-tips leak poison. Its fins and bones are highly valued as ingredients in herbal medicine.

Generation V.Black: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation V.White: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation V.Black 2: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional-medicine ingredients.
Generation V.White 2: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional-medicine ingredients.

Generation VI.X: Its body bristles with sharp spikes. Carelessly trying to touch it could cause fainting from the spikes.
Generation VI.Y: It is capable of swimming backwards by rapidly flapping its winglike pectoral fins and stout tail.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Seadra sleeps after wriggling itself between the branches of coral. Those trying to harvest coral are occasionally stung by this Pokémon's poison barbs if they fail to notice it.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Seadra generates whirlpools by spinning its body. The whirlpools are strong enough to swallow even fishing boats. This Pokémon weakens prey with these currents, then swallows it whole.

Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Touching the back fin causes numbness. It hooks its tail to coral to stay in place while sleeping.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Touching the back fin causes numbness. It hooks its tail to coral to stay in place while sleeping.

Generation VIII.Sword: It's the males that raise the offspring. While Seadra are raising young, the spines on their backs secrete thicker and stronger poison.
Generation VIII.Shield: Seadra's mouth is slender, but its suction power is strong. In an instant, Seadra can suck in food that's larger than the opening of its mouth.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: Its spines provide protection. Its fins and bones are prized as traditional medicine ingredients.

Generation IX.Scarlet: The male raises the young. If it is approached while caring for young, it will use its toxic spines to fend off the intruder.
Generation IX.Violet: Its fin tips leak poison. Its fins and bones are highly valued as ingredients in herbal medicine.

Generation I.Red: Seafoam Islands Route 23 and Cerulean Cave ( Super Rod )
Generation I.Blue: Route 23 and Cerulean Cave ( Super Rod )
Generation I.Blue (Japan): Route 23 and Cerulean Cave ( Super Rod )

Generation IV.SoulSilver: Seafoam Islands ( Super Rod ), Whirl Islands ( Surfing and Super Rod )

Generation V.White: Routes 17 and 18 , P2 Laboratory ( Fishing in rippling water )

Generation V.White 2: Routes 17 and 18 , P2 Laboratory ( Fishing in rippling water )
